title.narrative: Diakonia - Human Rights and Governance Program
Diakonia - Human Rights and Governance Program

description.narrative:
Det demokratiska utrymmet i Kenya har kontinuerligt minskat sedan den nuvarande regeringen kom till makten 2013. Det har blivit mycket svårare att arbeta med demokrati och mänskliga rättighetsfrågor, speciellt för civilsamhälles organisationer, jämfört med det mer öppna och tillåtande klimatet som rådde mellan 2003 och 2013.
I Kenya har det svenska biståndet ett nära samarbete med och stöd till en rad olika offentliga institutioner, bl a polisen, kriminalvården och domstolsväsendet. Numer är det allmänt vedertaget att om man kombinerar stöd till institutioner på nationell nivå för att genomföra reformer med stöd till lokal nivå, får man bättre och mer hållbara resultat. Detta program kommer att komplettera det stöd som Sverige ger till de statliga institutionerna, med stöd till en rad olika civilsamhällesorganisationer. Dessa stöd kommer att komplettera varandra för bättre genomslag. Civilsamhällesorganisationerna kommer också att ta sig an den viktiga watch-dog funktionen och därmed i förlängningen förbättra regeringens och kommunernas ansvarsskyldighet och tjänsteleverans.
Diakonia har inkommit med ett programförslag "Human Rights and Governance Program in Kenya" 2015-2019 om 95 000 000 SEK. Programmets övergripande mål är: 1) Improved access to justice through effective key institutions within the justice sector that respects human rights and the rule of law 2) Effective advocacy carried out by media and stakeholders in civil society at local and national level in order to strengthen democratic culture and increased accountability. Programmet utgör ett ramverk för stöd till civil samhället med målsättning att stärka civilsamhällets röst, påverkansarbete och ansvarsutkrävande, samt för att förbättra offentliga institutioners ansvarstagande och effektivitet.
Innan vi valde att bereda programförslaget från Diakonia så träffade ambassaden ett stort antal kenyanska civilsamhällsorganisationer för att diskutera hur ett svenskt stöd till civilsamhället skulle kunna se ut. Ett mycket tydligt budskap förmedlades av organisationerna, om Sverige skulle stödja en paraplymekanism så bör avtalsparten var en svensk eller internationell organisation, dels för att undvika anklagelser och misstankar om korruption, samt för att inte störa balansen mellan de inhemska organisationerna vad det gäller makt och inflytande.
Ambassaden kommer att skriva avtal med Diakonia som i sin tur kommer att ingå avtal med de civilsamhällesorganisationer som ingår i programmet. 12 civilsamhällesorganisationer är initialt med i programmet och ambitionen är att knyta till sig nya organisationer och/eller projekt under programmets gång för att snabbt kunna respondera eller ta tillfälle i akt om möjlighet ges för bra och relevanta initiativ inom ramen för detta program. Ambitionshöjningen är i dagsläget helt avhängig tillskjutandet av ytterligare medel från Ambassadens sida, eftersom Ambassaden fick lov att dra ner avtalsbeloppen pga minskade anslag. Ett annat alternativ är att andra givare går in och stödjer programmet. Eftersom Sverige befinner sig mitt emellan två strategiperioder kan vi endast ingå avtal med aktivitetsperiod fram till 2017 års slut (dvs. 2015-2017 - 45 000 000 SEK). Intentionen från ambassadens sida är dock att stödja hela programperioden.

The democratic space in Kenya has continuously been shrinking since the current government came into power after the elections in 2013. The environment for governance and human rights work, in particularly for civil society organisations, is much more cumbersome compared to what existed between 2003 and March 2013.
Diakonia has submitted a program proposal "Human Rights and Governance Program in Kenya" 2015-2019 for 95 000 000 SEK. The proposed program will have two objectives: 1) Improved Access to Justice through effective key institutions within the justice sector that respects human rights and the rule of law. 2) Effective advocacy carried out by media and stakeholders in civil society at local and national level in order to strengthen democratic culture and increased accountability. As Sweden is in between two strategy periods we will only be able to enter into an agreement that supports activities till the end of 2017 (i.e 2015-2017 - 45 000 000 SEK). The intention is however that we will support the whole program period.
In Kenya, the Swedish development cooperation have a close cooperation with and support to the government institutions working with the criminal justice chain and devolution. Institutional support needs to be combined with a strong grass roots approach. It is generally known by now that when you combine reforms and actions at the national level with a grassroots approach, the likelihood for successful reforms with good results and long-lasting development is so much greater. The proposed program will match the Swedish support to the institutions working with the justice chain, police, prisons and probation with support to a wide range of civil society organisations, in the same areas for better effect and cross fertilization, but also for taking on the very important watch-dog function for enhancing accountability and the service delivery by the government and the counties.
Before the assessment of the proposal the Embassy had consultations with a large number of Kenyan civil society organisations for discussing how a Swedish support to the civil society could and should look like. A very clear message was sent from the organisations consulted. If Sweden was to consider an umbrella solution, the organisation in charge of such a solution should be Swedish or international for avoiding corruption and/or suspicion of corruption and for not distorting the balance between the domestic organisations.
Diakonia will be the agreement partner to Sida. Diakonia, in turn will enter into sub-agreements with the 13 civil society organisations that will be engaged in the programme. The ambition is to be able to bring on more partners during the course of the program for being able to respond to upcoming situations or seizing opportunities. The increase in ambition is dependent on additional funds from the Embassy's side, since the Embassy at the last moment had to decrease the fund due to budget reallocations, or alternatively that other donors joint the programme.

There are two intended outcomes of this proposed programme are:1. Improved access to justice through effective key institutions within the justice sector that respects human rights and the rule of law.2. Effective advocacy carried out by media and stakeholders in civil society at local and national level in order to strengthen democratic culture and increased accountability.

description.narrative: 1 July 2015 - 31 December 2017 The first phase of the program ran from 1 July 2015 to 31 July 2018 (originally the end date was set to 31 December 2017). This was a period in time when many Kenyans held high expectations on improvement of the respect for human rights and democratic governance as a consequence of the devolved governance structure and other democratic structures as envisioned in the 2010 Constitution of Kenya, as well as the elections and aftermath in 2013. Many challenges in respect to human rights, gender equality and democratic governance persisted and the program´s forcus on access to justice, democratic culture and accountability were deemed relevant as reported in the Midline evaluation report which covers the program from inception to October 2017. In regards to access to justice, the program has contributed to building trust between local police and communities through dialogue forums in target counties. This improved reported satisfaction with services delivered by the police to citizens. The police and community dialogues also had bearing during the prolonged election period in 2017 as citizens reported that the local police were behaving responsibly (while the police deployed from the National Police Service (NPS) as rapid response often did not). There is no doubt that there is a long way until Kenyan police is fully accountable but these improvements still deserve to be noted. Improved knowledge amongst the police on police welfare as well as advocacy on the way traffic offences are handled have also contributed to the pace of police reforms. Access to courts for indigent populations was improved due to development of frameworks for Alternative Dispute Resolutions (ADR) and Traditional Dispute Resolution Mechanisms (TDRM), as well as strengthening of Court User Committees (CUCs). Customer care and paralegal services in court stations were also enhanced in court stations. In Tana River County out of court outreaches were made to reach populations in locations that are difficult to reach. These initiatives enhanced access to courts and ADR mechanisms. In the justice institutions such as Prisons, Probation and Aftercare noted similar achievements in the program, including establishment of policy frameworks on sentencing, enhanced bond and bail for petty offenders and strengthened structures to review the criminal system, as well as improved capacity of officers. There are other actors involved in this area and although the evaluation gives the program credit for these improvements, it is reasonable to assume the program played a very important role in the targeted counties, while the national changes (including the implementation of the Persons Deprived of Liberty Act) were the result of many actors - not least reform minded staff in the judiciary sector. During the No Cost Extension (NCE) period (1 January to 31 July 2018) this result area reported greater buy in and ownership by communities in the target counties and increased collaboration between the Judiciary and community in advancing the rights of the people in the counties where the program advocated the use of ADR and TDRM. The work with the police also continued to develop and greater involvement with communities and their representatives when conducting operations in their areas as one example. In Isiolo the Administration Police (AP) and Kenya Police Service (KPS) carried out joint operations, instead of previously uncoordinated operations which often have resulted in the police killing each other. An increase in police responsiveness as a result of the Community Policing Forums and County Policing Committees were noted by Diakonia and new forums were initiated to address crime and insecurity issues. Improved public understanding on community policing and their role in regards to public safety and security was achieved by using media talkshows to engage national and local radio stations to sensitize on human rights and issues of access to justice. Development and launch of the Anonymous Reporting and Information System (ARIS), a long awaited toll-free phone line, was finally launched through partnership of one program partner, the NPS and UNODC. The system will enable citizens to confidentially report malpractices and other complaints they have to the Internal Affairs Unit (IAU) of the police. Accomplishments under the NCE period Public paticipation law development was completed in Mandera and Tana River counties. There was a general increase in the number of citizens participating in various public processes. Youth representation to the County Budget and Economic Forums in Uasin Gishu and Nandi counties facilitates a stronger voice by youth in economic planning and budgeting. The program has interacted with county governments´ to improve service delivery which has led to introductions of service charters in the health and education sector, improving the quality and recognition of institutions; Tana River Level 5 hospital and Mtongwe polytechnic among others. Dialogues have also been held with County governments to improve the working environment for CSOs at the devolved level. Positive changes have been noted, particularly in Bungoma, Kajiado and Kakamega county where CSOs are collaborating with the county governments in developing and monitoring policies. The program has been active in the national dialogues for cohesion, both in the 'Kenya we want' forums and in the 'Building Bridges Initiative', working for the inclusion of the views of wanjiku/mwananchi (names used in reference of common female/male citizens). A special effort has been made on integration of youth at risk of radicalisation, including recommendations to national and county governments. The often violent competition for water and land - increasing due to climate change - by farmers and pastoralists was addressed in Tana River, resulting in several agreements, for which the responsibility of implementation lie with the clan elders. The first citizen budget in the country was produced in Nairobi county as a result of the cooperation of a program partner and the Institute of Public Finance. It is perceived that this will be a useful tool in advocacy and enhancement of budget literacy among non-specialists hence improving participation in budgetary processes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
